Award.AwardTitle: Development of Flexible Microsystems for Bacterial Biofilm Management

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacterial biofilms, a major cause of infection and environmental biofouling, are difficult to remove and contribute to the rapid increase in antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains. They often induce catastrophic consequences in an array of inaccessible environments with complex curved geometries, ultimately leading to persistent infections, implant failure, and systemic contamination. There is demand for viable methods to detect, prevent, and remove biofilms in locales including urinary catheters, prosthetic implants, and water systems, where currently effective methods do not exist to detect and eradicate biofilms. Advances in flexible device technology yield opportunities for feedback-driven biofilm management systems for operation in these vulnerable areas. The objective is to develop a paradigm enabling dynamic flexible sensor microsystems for detecting, monitoring, and inhibiting biofilms on multidimensional surfaces, in particular the cylindrical environment of a urinary catheter. The surface bacterial species, fluid conditions, and geometry are the basis for this approach, creating a guide for identifying methods of biofilm detection and prevention on demand. Successful monitoring and removal of biofilm will have a dramatic impact, improving quality of life for people of all demographics. These systems have the potential to reduce the spread of antibiotic-resistant and healthcare-acquired infections, and are particularly attractive for addressing these challenges in resource-poor regions. Moreover, the potential for low-cost manufacturing of these devices will enable their inclusion by high school teachers into laboratory-based STEM curricula.

To systematically develop this methodology, the objective of this proposal is divided into three tasks: 1) Optimization of microsystems for sensing and inhibiting biofilms in complex, 3D environments: Thin film electrodes will be selected as a simple and sensitive electrochemical impedance sensor, tested in a microfluidic system as a sensor and biofilm inhibitor via the bioelectric effect. Furthermore, the device will be optimized for biofilm detection via a computational model. The model will examine changes in the electric field of the sensor for the relevant geometry. 2) Manufacturing of integrated flexible devices for biofilms: appropriate materials and fabrication processes are determined by specific geometric and environmental requirements of each application, notably flexible substrates, such as polyimide, with gold as an inert electrode material. The flexible substrates will enable folding and scaling of the device as required to interface with the vulnerable complex curved surface. 3) Device testing using environmental model with data transmission and feedback control: A urinary catheter will serve as a test case. This will be developed considering the unique geometric, bacterial, and fluidic conditions. 3D-printed structures precisely recreate geometry interactions with biofilm, where sensor response and bioelectric treatment will be evaluated simultaneously. A wireless controlled (using Bluetooth or Wifi) electronic system will be developed to operate the impedance sensor and control the biofilm removal using the electrodes will be developed. Feedback-driven dynamic biofilm control will be developed, considering threshold impedance sensing values corresponding to biofilm biomass. The system will introduce a bioelectric effect treatment based on impedance sensor data indicating the formation of a biofilm in real-time. This project addresses the challenge of preventing, identifying, and removing biofilms on a complex surface. An interdisciplinary approach combining applied microbiology and engineering disciplines is required to overcome these problems. Complex interactions between flexible sensors, bacterial biofilms, and bioelectric treatment will be explored. Electrical reduction of biofilm enables remote programmability in vulnerable systems. The impact on system design of key parameters including bacterial species, surface geometry, and fluidic conditions will be clearly enumerated. The fundamental methodology developed here will enable further research to address biofilm monitoring and removal in areas of dire need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacterial biofilms are formed by a community of one or multiple types of microorganisms that adhere to a surface and form an organized ecosystem that enhances their growth and defense mechanisms. They are responsible for approximately 65 percent of implant-associated infections and are very hard to remove, contributing to the rapid increase in antibiotic-resistant effects with serious consequences to patients. Specifically, catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) are a very common problem in the healthcare system since catheters are often used for prolonged periods. An indwelling catheter will eventually become colonized by biofilm, leading to urinary tract infections and blockages. Current monitoring methods are either time-consuming, taking and analyzing regular urine samples, or are too unspecific, measuring the urine flow rate. Therefore, there is an increasing demand for non-expensive methods to detect, prevent, and remove biofilms in medical devices, especially for urinary catheters and prosthetic implants. Monitoring and prevention is also important in water systems, where acquiring biological data is difficult, partly because most pipes and devices have curved surfaces that require the use of flexible sensors. 

The objective of this project was to develop a paradigm to enable dynamic flexible sensor microsystems for detecting, monitoring, and inhibiting biofilms on multidimensional surfaces.

The specific objectives were divided in three tasks: 1) Design of microsystems for sensing and inhibiting biofilms: Thin film electrodes were selected as a simple and sensitive electrochemical impedance sensor. Electric field-based biofilm inhibition and removal was investigated. Impedance microsystem optimization was achieved via a computational model considering the full complexity of biofilm and the changes in the sensor electric field for relevant geometries. 2) Manufacturing of integrated flexible devices for biofilms: Appropriate materials and fabrication processes were determined by specific geometric and environmental requirements of each application. These materials enable folding and scaling the device to make it fit into a catheter. Long-term reliability was also evaluated within the context of the application requirements. 3) Device testing on representative environment models with data transmission and feedback control: The device’s performance was evaluated on microfluidic channels and urinary catheters.

The project has ended with a working prototype of a flexible impedance sensor that can be bent and adapted to curved surfaces, allowing us to monitor the growth of the biofilm in real-time. The formation of a biofilm changes the electrode interface, producing a variation in the relative resistance and capacitive profile (impedance) used as the sensor signal. This same system can simultaneously implement the bioelectric effect (BE) for biofilm removal. The BE consists of applying an electric current that can trigger electrochemical reactions that enhance the activity of antimicrobial agents against certain bacteria.

A strategy for fabricating electrodes directly on cylindrical surfaces was successfully demonstrated on catheters but can be generalized to other applications such as water purification systems or drinking water pipes. In addition, the custom PCB and mobile application enables user-friendly wireless control and data transmission. The device can also serve as a discovery platform for future research, capable of generating real-time, in situ data regarding biofilm formation in a way that is not currently possible. The performance of both the sensing and treatment was evaluated in a realistic in-vitro bladder model, demonstrating the viability of this approach for future clinical in-vivo studies. The final prototype system is simple, low power, and has the potential to be applied to other implantable medical devices. This reduces cost, eliminates unnecessary antibiotic usage, and improves public health. We hope that this technology will help the industry and healthcare providers to foresee and treat biofilm related infections.
